Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.58]
LES conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.60]
LES promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The facility’s RMP process has had no RMP-reportable accidents in the past 5 years.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
In the event of an incident, LES has systems in place to respond quickly. Processes can be shut down on an emergency basis and the facility has a plan in place for evacuations, adequate first aid, and medical treatment and notification of local emergency response agencies. The facility is a responding facility, with trained personnel to respond in the event of an emergency and utilizes an Emergency Response Plan to document procedures for responding in the event of an accidental release of a regulated chemical. LES also utilizes on the LEPC for Lancaster County to respond to chemical releases.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
LES has completed their hazard review as well as their compliance audit within the last year. We are working to address the recommendations appropriately and within a timely manner.

LES has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that the many controls instituted to maint

155(c)]:
LES has a program in place to comply with the provisions of program level 2 of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.48]
LES maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Hazard Review [40 CFR Part 68.50]
Comprehensive analyses ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The studies ensure processes are designed, fabricated, and operated in accordance with the applicable standards. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.52]
To ensure safe operations, LES  maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.54]
LES has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Maintenance [40 CFR Part 68.56]
LES carries out documented maintenance checks and inspections on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipmen

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
Rokeby Generating Station, owned and operated by Lincoln Electric System (LES), is the stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan. LES is a publicly owned electric utility with sole service responsibility in and around Lincoln, Nebraska. As a public owned utility, LES operates and maintains all of the equipment in our system in a manner representing prudent utility practices and in conformance with the expectations of LES customers and owners. LES strives for excellence in the facility operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and regulations. 

Meeting environmental requirements is part of LES business practices and by maintaining this Risk Management Program, LES is complying with the Federal Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and the Risk Management Program defined in it. LES is committed to the accidental release prevention program and also maintains a detailed Emergency Response Plan designated specifically for the Rokeby Generating Station. This plan is routinely reviewed with HAZMAT responder organizations.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The Rokeby Station provides emergency, peaking, and base load electric power generation by utilizing one or more of the three dual fuel combustion turbines, two diesel blackstart engines, and one fuel oil storage tank located on the 160-acre site. To augment power output during high summer air temperatures, a cooling system is used to lower turbine inlet air temperatures. The cooling system uses ammonia refrigeration to make ice that is stored in two separate concrete tanks and consists of Ice System #1 and Ice System #2. The total quantity of the anhydrous ammonia exceeds EPA’s RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.
